notes.text:
[**2155-6-1**] 3:44 PM
 CT ABDOMEN W/CONTRAST; CT PELVIS W/CONTRAST                     Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 80062**]
 Reason: Will need PO contrast, please be sure to do venous phase, as
 Admitting Diagnosis: ABDOMINAL PAIN
  Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 130
 ______________________________________________________________________________
 [**Hospital 2**] MEDICAL CONDITION:
  56 year old man with s/p whipple procedure, now with billious emesis.  Had SMV
  reconstruction
 REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
  Will need PO contrast, please be sure to do venous phase, as pt had
  reconstruction
 No contraindications for IV contrast
 ______________________________________________________________________________
 WET READ: JXKc SUN [**2155-6-1**] 5:55 PM
  1.  Small locules of free air inferior to the liver, atypical given time
  course from surgery, correlate clinically.
  2.  Gastric distension, without evidence of obstruction as contrast passes
  distally into colon.
  3.  Small ascites, simliar to prior study.
  4.  Bilateral lower lobe consolidation, may reflect aspiration or pneumonia.
 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT
 HISTORY:  Status post Whipple, now with bilious emesis, had SMV
 reconstruction.

 COMPARISON:  [**2155-5-26**].

 TECHNIQUE:  MDCT axial images were obtained from the lung bases through the
 symphysis pubis with the administration of IV and oral contrast.  Coronal and
 sagittal reformations were obtained.

 CT OF THE ABDOMEN WITH IV CONTRAST:  Massive consolidation of bilateral lower
 lobes are concerning for aspiration given the provided history.  There are
 trace bilateral pleural effusions.  The visualized heart and pericardium are
 without pericardial effusion.

 Patient is status post Whipple procedure, with SMV reconstruction.  Marked
 narrowing just proximal to the splenic vein insertion is stable in appearance
 from prior study.  Thrombosis of the right anterior portal venous system is
 stable.  The liver is otherwise unremarkable.  There has been prior
 cholecystectomy, with multiple locules of free air noted inferior to the
 gallbladder [**Year (4 digits) 5917**], similar in appearance to prior study, without discrete
 adjacent fluid collection, and could reflect residual postoperative free air.
 The spleen, adrenal glands, and kidneys are notable for small rounded
 hypodensities in the right kidney, which are too small to characterize.

 An NG tube is in stomach, which is moderately distended, though contrast
 passes freely into the small and large bowel, without evidence for
 obstruction.  Previously noted collections adjacent to the Roux jejunal loop
 has resolved, as well as inferior to the liver tip have resolved.  Hypodensity
 in the expected region of the pancreatic head is stable in size measuring 3
 cm, with fiducial seeds noted.
                                                             (Over)

 [**2155-6-1**] 3:44 PM
 CT ABDOMEN W/CONTRAST; CT PELVIS W/CONTRAST                     Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 80062**]
 Reason: Will need PO contrast, please be sure to do venous phase, as
 Admitting Diagnosis: ABDOMINAL PAIN
  Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 130
 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT
 (Cont)

 Mild wall thickening involving the ascending colon, hepatic flexure and
 transverse colon likely reflect residual postoperative inflammatory change.

 CT OF THE PELVIS WITH IV CONTRAST:  The urinary bladder, rectum and prostate
 are unremarkable.  A moderate amount of free fluid in abdomen is similar in
 extent to prior study.

 OSSEOUS STRUCTURES:  A sclerotic lesion within the right aspect of the sacrum
 likely reflects a bone island, and is stable.  Osseous structures are
 otherwise unremarkable.

 SOFT TISSUES:  Surgical wounds along the anterior subcutaneous fat with
 subcutaneous air are noted.

 IMPRESSION:
 1.  Post-Whipple changes, with stable narrowing of the SMV just proximal to
 the splenic vein insertion into the portal vein.
 2.  Stable partial thrombosis of the right anterior portal vein.
 3.  Small locules of free air inferior to the gallbladder [**Last Name (LF) 5917**], [**First Name3 (LF) **] reflect
 residual postoperative air. There is no associated fluid or collection.
 4.  Essentially resolved fluid collections previously seen adjacent to the
 Roux jejunal loop as well as inferior to the liver.
 5.  Moderate gastric distention, though contrast passes freely through the
 small and large bowel without evidence for obstruction.
 6.  Moderate free fluid in the pelvis.
 7.  Massive bilateral lower lobe consolidations, concerning for aspiration.

 Findings were discussed with Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 3634**] immediately at the time of study.

[**2155-6-2**] 2:31 PM
 CHEST PORT. LINE PLACEMENT; -77 BY DIFFERENT PHYSICIAN          [**Name Initial (PRE) 7**] # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 80242**]
 Reason: pls assess tip of 50cm LUE basilic picc, call [**Doctor First Name 3245**] [**Numeric Identifier 2401**] w/
 Admitting Diagnosis: ABDOMINAL PAIN
 ______________________________________________________________________________
 [**Hospital 2**] MEDICAL CONDITION:
  56 year old man with new left picc
 REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
  pls assess tip of 50cm LUE basilic picc, call [**Doctor First Name 3245**] [**Numeric Identifier 2401**] w/ wet read thanks
 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT
 INDICATION:  56-year-old man with new left PICC placement.

 COMPARISON:  Chest radiograph [**2155-6-2**]

 SINGLE AP SEMI-UPRIGHT CHEST RADIOGRAPH:  A left PICC ends in the low SVC.  No
 post-procedural complications, especially no pneumothorax or mediastinal
 widening is detected.  Bilateral small pleural effusions and bibasal
 consolidations, have not significantly changed since the prior study and could
 represent an infectious process versus aspiration and/or atelectasis.  Mild
 pulmonary edema is unchanged.  The cardiac and mediastinal contours are
 normal.  The lung volumes are low.  A nasogastric tube ends in the gastric
 fundus after making a loop in the gastric body.

 IMPRESSION:
 1. Left PICC ends in the lower SVC.  No post-procedural complications
 detected.
 2.  Bibasal consolidations and bilateral small pleural effusions are unchanged
 since the previous study.

[**2155-6-4**] 9:48 AM
 CHEST (PORTABLE AP)                                             Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 80243**]
 Reason: ? resolution of acute process
 Admitting Diagnosis: ABDOMINAL PAIN
 ______________________________________________________________________________
 [**Hospital 2**] MEDICAL CONDITION:
  56 year old man with ? aspiration PNA
 REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
  ? resolution of acute process
 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT
 INDICATION:  56-year-old man with possible aspiration pneumonia, please assess
 for resolution.

 TECHNIQUE:  Semi-upright portable radiograph of the chest was obtained.

 COMPARISON:  Portable chest radiograph [**6-1**], 7 and 8, [**2154**].

 FINDINGS:
 The lung volumes are low.
 In the interval, there is worsening of the left retrocardiac opacity, and
 increase of the right basilar consolidation.  The cardiac silhouette appears
 slightly increased, likely positional.  No pulmonary edema.  Slightly
 increased moderate right and small left pleural effusions.   The mediastinum
 and hila are normal.  No acute bony or soft tissue abnormalities.  A NG tube
 ends in the gastric fundus.
 There is no pneumothorax.

 IMPRESSION:
 Worsening of bibasilar consolidations likely consistent with worsening pleural
 effusions and aspiration pneumonia.

History of Present Illness:

[**5-14**] for
pancreatic ca with SMV thrombosis ([**Doctor Last Name **] and [**Doctor Last Name **]),
with post-operative course marked by delayed gastric emptying,
requiring NGT reinsertion on POD 7 until POD 11.  The remainder

treated by opening up each corner of the incision and packing
with WTD dressings.  He was discharged home on [**2155-5-30**].
Yesterday
he developed some nausea, limiting his PO intake, which
progressed to emesis this morning of thin yellow-green fluid.
Reports mild abdominal pain, described as a tightness across his
upper abdomen in the region of the incision.  + flatus yesterday
but not today.  Last BM was yesterday.  Denies fevers or chills.

.

[**2155-4-24**] EUS.

grandchildren. No tobacco use history, 1 drink EtOH/month, no
recreational drugs.  He is only sexually active with his wife.

adjacent to the
Roux jejunal loop as well as inferior to the liver.

through the
small and large bowel without evidence for obstruction.

aspiration

complications
detected.

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was discharged home on [**2155-5-30**] s/p Whipple
resection and SMV reconstruction. On [**2155-6-1**] patient was
readmitted to the General Surgical Service with c/o
nausea/vomiting and decreased PO intake. On admission in ED,
patient continue to have active and continuous emesis of thin
yellow-fluid. Patient was tachycardic with HRmax 130s, chest
xray revealed aspiration pneumonia. Patient was intubated for
airway protection and transferred in ICU for observation and
treatment.

Neuro: The patient received propofol and fentanyl for sedation
while intubated. After extubation, patient's pain was controlled
with IV Dilaudid with good effect and adequate pain control.
When tolerating oral intake, the patient was transitioned to
oral pain medications. Currently patient taking Tylenol for pain
control.

CV: On admission patient was tachycardic, after he was hydrated
patient HR returned to [**Location 213**] sinus rhythm. Patient heart rate
was monitored with telemetry during hospitalization. The patient
remained stable from a cardiovascular standpoint; vital signs
were routinely monitored.

Pulmonary: On admission patient had active emeses, and chest xr
revealed aspiration pneumonia. Patient was intubated and
transferred in ICU. On [**6-2**] patient was extubated, he was
required 3-4 L of O2 via n/c for O2 Sats > 92%. Patient was
transferred on the floor, where he continue to be monitored for
O2 Sats. He continue require 2L O2, his O2 Sats 95-97%. Last
chest pa/lat demonstrated that pulmonary edema has markedly
improved and now mild; bibasilar consolidations larger on the
left side and consistent with pneumonia; there is no
pneumothorax. Patient was started on Vancomycin and Zosyn on
admission, late Erythromycin was added to his treatment. Patient
currently stable from pulmonary standpoint, he will continue ABX
treatment after discharge.

GI/GU/FEN: Patient was made NPO on admission and started on TPN.
His diet was advanced to clears on HD # 8. Patient will continue
TPN on discharge. His diet will be advanced slowly within 2
weeks to fulls, with no solid food allowed until follow up with
Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **] (Surgery). Electrolytes were routinely followed, and
repleted when necessary.

ID: The patient's white blood count and fever curves were
closely watched for signs of infection. On admission patient's
WBC was elevated, but currently WNL. Patient remained afebrile
during hospitalization. Blood, urine and sputum cultures were
negative.

Endocrine: Patient has a history of diet controlled diabetes.
After TPN was started, patient's BS was continue to increase and
required increased TPN insulin, standing insulin order and high
sliding scale for BS control. Currently patient's FS between
90s-200s. Patient will require close blood sugar monitor when
his TPN will started to wean off.

Hematology: The patient's complete blood count was examined
routinely, his Hct was stable low (23.1-24.6). On [**6-5**] patient
received one unit of RBC, after transfusion Hct was 24.6. On
[**6-6**] patient received one more unit of RBC, his Hct was 29.2
after second transfusion. After blood transfusions, patient
reported increase of energy and patient's O2 requirements
decreased from 5L to 3L.

Prophylaxis: The patient received subcutaneous heparin and
venodyne boots were used during this stay; was encouraged to get
up and ambulate as early as possible. There was concern for a
LUE DVT during his stay b/c of some swelling at and around the
PICC site, but an ultrasound was performed that showed no clot
and the swelling improved with elevation.

At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile
with stable vital signs. The patient was tolerating a clear
fluid diet and TPN, ambulating with stand by assist, voiding
without assistance, and pain was well controlled. The patient
received discharge teaching and follow-up instructions with
understanding verbalized and agreement with the discharge plan.

Medications on Admission:
ASA 325', norvasc 10', losartan 25', indapamide 2.5', lipitor
10', protonix 40', reglan 10''', colace 100''prn, senna
8.6''prn, dilaudid 2-4q4:prn, tylenol prn


Discharge Medications:
1. Albuterol Sulfate 2.5 mg /3 mL (0.083 %) Solution for
Nebulization Sig: One (1) NEB Inhalation Q4H (every 4 hours).
2. Insulin Glargine 100 unit/mL Solution Sig: Fifteen (15) units
Subcutaneous at bedtime.
3. Insulin Regular Human 100 unit/mL Solution Sig: 4-32 units
Injection as directed.
4. Acetaminophen 325 mg Tablet Sig: 1-2 Tablets PO Q6H (every 6
hours) as needed for pain.
5. Aspirin 325 mg Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) Sig: One (1)
Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) PO DAILY (Daily).
6. Erythromycin 500 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q12H (every
12 hours).
7. Losartan 25 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily).
8. Amlodipine 10 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily).

9. Atorvastatin 10 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY
(Daily).
10. Pantoprazole 40 mg Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) Sig: One
(1) Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) PO once a day.
11. Heparin Flush (10 units/ml) 2 mL IV PRN line flush
PICC, heparin dependent: Flush with 10mL Normal Saline followed
by Heparin as above daily and PRN per lumen.
12. Reglan 10 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO every eight (8)
hours.
13. Vancomycin 500 mg Recon Soln Sig: 1250 (1250) mg Intravenous
twice a day for 4 days.
14. Zosyn 4.5 gram Recon Soln Sig: One (1)  Intravenous every
eight (8) hours for 4 days.
15. Dilaudid 2 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO every four (4)
hours as needed for pain.
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*


Discharge Disposition:
Extended Care

Facility:
[**Hospital1 700**] - [**Location (un) 701**]

Discharge Diagnosis:
1. Pancreatic adenocarcinoma with SMV thrombosis
2. Delayed gastric emptying
3. Aspiration PNA


Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker
or cane).


Discharge Instructions:
Please resume all regular home medications , unless specifically
advised not to take a particular medication. Also, please take
any new medications as prescribed.
Please get plenty of rest, continue to ambulate several times
per day, and drink adequate amounts of fluids. Avoid lifting
weights greater than [**5-5**] lbs until you follow-up with your
surgeon, who will instruct you further regarding activity
restrictions.
Avoid driving or operating heavy machinery while taking pain
medications.
Please follow-up with your surgeon and Primary Care Provider
(PCP) as advised.

Incision Care:
*Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner if you have
increased pain, swelling, redness, or drainage from the incision
site.
*Avoid swimming and baths until your follow-up appointment.
*You may shower, and wash surgical incisions with a mild soap
and warm water. Gently pat the area dry.
*If you have staples, they will be removed at your follow-up
appointment.
*If you have steri-strips, they will fall off on their own.
Please remove any remaining strips 7-10 days after surgery.
Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner if you experience
the following:
*You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or
tightness.
*New or worsening cough, shortness of breath, or wheeze.
*If you are vomiting and cannot keep down fluids or your
medications.
*You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, diarrhea,
or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry mouth, rapid
heartbeat, or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.
*You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a
bowel movement.
*You experience burning when you urinate, have blood in your
urine, or experience a discharge.
*Your pain is not improving within 8-12 hours or is not gone
within 24 hours. Call or return immediately if your pain is
getting worse or changes location or moving to your chest or
back.
*You have shaking chills, or fever greater than 101.5 degrees
Fahrenheit or 38 degrees Celsius.
*Any change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that concern
you.

PICC line care:
*Please monitor the site regularly, and [**Name6 (MD) 138**] your MD, nurse
practitioner, or [**Name6 (MD) 269**] Nurse if you notice redness, swelling,
tenderness or pain, drainage or bleeding at the insertion site.
* [**Name6 (MD) **] your MD [**First Name (Titles) **] [**Last Name (Titles) 10836**] to the Emergency Room immediately if
the PICC Line tubing becomes damaged or punctured, or if the
line is pulled out partially or completely. DO NOT USE THE PICC
LINE IN THESE CIRCUMSTANCES.Please keep the dressing clean and
dry. Contact your [**Name2 (NI) 269**] Nurse if the dressing comes undone or is
significantly soiled for further instructions.


Followup Instructions:
Please follow up with Dr. [**First Name (STitle) **] (PCP) in [**1-29**] weeks after
discharge
.

[**2155-6-1**] 2:50 PM
 PORTABLE ABDOMEN                                                Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 79768**]
 Reason: ? perf vs obstr
 ______________________________________________________________________________
 [**Hospital 2**] MEDICAL CONDITION:
  56 year old man with vomiting s/p whipple
 REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
  ? perf vs obstr
 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT
 REASON FOR EXAM:  Status post Whipple's.  Rule out perforation or bowel
 obstruction.

 COMPARISON:  CT abdomen and pelvis from [**2155-5-26**].

 SINGLE SUPINE VIEW OF THE ABDOMEN:  The upper portion of the abdomen is not
 imaged and therefore evaluation for pneumoperitoneum is not possible.  The
 abdomen is gasless.  Underlying bowel loops, either collapsed or possbile
 fluid-filled, cannot be assessed for dilatation.  A loop of colon in the right
 side of the abdomen as well as in the left pelvis contains air and stool.
 Osseous structures demonstrate degenerative changes of the hips.  There is
 likely bone island in the right side of the sacrum, better seen on prior CT.

 IMPRESSION:  Gasless abdomen.  Bowel obstruction cannot be excluded.  Clinical
 correlation is recommended.

 INDICATION:  56-year-old man with left upper extremity swelling.  ? venous
 thrombosis.

 FINDINGS:  Patent flow is seen on color Doppler imaging of the left internal
 jugular vein and the right internal jugular vein.  The left subclavian vein
 has patent flow on color and Doppler imaging.  There is normal flow,

 basilic vein.  PICC line is identified within the left basilic vein.

[**2155-6-1**] 1:33 PM
 CHEST (PORTABLE AP)                                             Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 79767**]
 Reason: ? perf vs obstr
 ______________________________________________________________________________
 [**Hospital 2**] MEDICAL CONDITION:
  56 year old man with vomiting s/p whipple
 REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
  ? perf vs obstr
 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT
 REASON FOR EXAM:  Status post Whipple's procedure, presents with vomiting.
 Clinical concern for free air.

 COMPARISON:  Multiple chest radiographs with the most recent from [**2155-5-26**].

 SINGLE FRONTAL VIEW OF THE CHEST:  There is no evidence of pneumoperitoneum.
 Low lung volumes limit evaluation.  An NG tube with the tip likely within the
 fundus of the stomach is noted.  Bilateral small pleural effusions are noted.
 There is new bilateral lower lobe reticular and nodular opacities as well as
 retrocardiac opacity which likely represent aspiration pneumonia. Upper
 abdominal surgical clips are again noted.

 IMPRESSION:
 1.  Bilateral lower lobe opacities most compatible with aspiration pneumonia.
 2. No pneumoperitoneum.

 Discussed with Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **] at 5:12 pm [**2155-6-1**].
